main_text:
Thomas Paine was a pamphleteer, controversialist and international
revolutionary. His Common Sense (1776) was a central text
behind the call for American independence from Britain; his Rights
of Man (1791–2) was the most widely read pamphlet in the
movement for reform in Britain in the 1790s and for the opening
decades of the nineteenth century; he was active in the French
Revolution and was a member of the French National Convention between
1792 and 1795; he is seen by many as a key figure in the emergence of
claims for the state’s responsibilities for welfare and
educational provision, and his Age of Reason provided a
popular deist text that remained influential throughout the
19th century. In his own lifetime, and subsequently, he has
been extensively vilified and often dismissed. Yet many of his ideas
still command wide interest and enthusiasm in readers throughout the
world.
